title: 105_hr3997
content: The Act titled "Medicare Consumer Bill of Rights Conforming Act of 1998" ensures access to obstetrician-gynecologists. The Act titled "Medicare Consumer Bill of Rights Conforming Act of 1998" ensures access to obstetrical and gynecological care by allowing Medicare+Choice enrollees to designate a participating physician specializing in obstetrics and gynecology as their primary care provider. The Act allows Medicare+Choice enrollees to designate an obstetrics and gynecology specialist as their primary care provider, granting coverage for routine gynecological care and pregnancy-related services without the need for authorization or referral. The Act allows Medicare+Choice enrollees to designate an obstetrics and gynecology specialist as their primary care provider, granting coverage for routine gynecological care and pregnancy-related services without the need for authorization or referral. Additionally, the ordering of other gynecological care by the specialist may be treated as authorized by the primary care provider under the plan, without waiving coverage requirements for medical necessity or appropriateness. The Act ensures continuity of care for Medicare+Choice enrollees by allowing them to designate an obstetrics and gynecology specialist as their primary care provider, granting coverage for routine gynecological care and pregnancy-related services without the need for authorization or referral. Section 1852 of the Social Security Act is amended to include a new subsection regarding Assuring Continuity of Care for Medicare+Choice enrollees undergoing treatment from a provider whose contract is terminated. The organization must notify the individual in a timely manner of such termination. The new subsection in Section 1852 of the Social Security Act ensures continuity of care for Medicare+Choice enrollees when a provider's contract is terminated. The organization must notify the individual promptly and allow them to continue treatment during a transitional period. Terminated contracts include expiration or nonrenewal, but not termination for quality standards or fraud. The transitional period for continuity of care under Section 1852 of the Social Security Act extends for at least 90 days from the provider's termination notice. It includes institutional care until discharge or termination of institutionalization, and care scheduled before the termination announcement. The transitional period for continuity of care under Section 1852 of the Social Security Act extends for at least 90 days from the provider's termination notice. It includes care for pregnant enrollees in the second trimester and terminally ill enrollees. The transitional period for continuity of care under Section 1852 of the Social Security Act extends for the remainder of the individual's life for terminally ill patients, with permissible terms and conditions for coverage by Medicare+Choice organizations. The provider must adhere to quality assurance standards and payment rates set by the organization responsible for payment, without exceeding cost-sharing limits for the individual. The provider must adhere to the organization's policies and procedures, including referrals, prior authorization, and treatment plans. This subsection does not require coverage of benefits that would not have been covered if the provider remained a participating provider. The amendments made by this Act will apply to Medicare+Choice organizations for contracts with the Secretary of Health and Human Services starting more than 90 days after the enactment of this Act.
